text: Does anyone bet into the Hong Kong pools?

elements.text: Does anyone bet into the Hong Kong pools?

text: You mean for racing? I didn’t think they gave access outside HK and wouldn’t have an official API. Or are you talking more grey area betting?

elements.text: You mean for racing? I didn’t think they gave access outside HK and wouldn’t have an official API. Or are you talking more grey area betting?

text: Yes, racing

elements.text: Yes, racing

text:
This article: <https://www.racingpost.com/news/how-you-can-bet-on-the-international-races-in-the-enormous-hong-kong-pools/356778> says:

> Hong Kong tote bets can be placed at high street betting shops including Betfred, Coral, Ladbrokes and William Hill, while online bets can be placed with Betfred, Coral, William Hill, Totepool, Black Type and BetPoint.

attachments.title: How you can bet on the International races in the enormous Hong Kong pools | Horse Racing News | Racing Post
attachments.text: The popularity of Hong Kong racing around the world continues to rise, with commingling into the world?s largest tote pool growing rapidly.
attachments.fallback: How you can bet on the International races in the enormous Hong Kong pools | Horse Racing News | Racing Post

elements.text: This article:
says:

Hong Kong tote bets can be placed at high street betting shops including Betfred, Coral, Ladbrokes and William Hill, while online bets can be placed with Betfred, Coral, William Hill, Totepool, Black Type and BetPoint.

text:
But that's pretty much all of the information I could find on how I, as a UK resident, can bet into the pools (legitimately). Also, the really interesting thing is not betting into the standard pools but the exotics like tierce and there's even less information about those. The article says

> The Hong Kong pools offer plenty of different bet types which are set to be rolled out over the coming months.
But this article is from 2018 ...

elements.text: But that's pretty much all of the information I could find on how I, as a UK resident, can bet into the pools (legitimately). The Hong Kong pools offer plenty of different bet types which are set to be rolled out over the coming months.

text: I’ve never looked into that before. Could be quite interesting though. Quite a bit of work betting programmatically with bookmakers though? Although there might be 3rd-party APIs you could go through I guess. Not sure about how widely exotics bets are exposed through those providers though.

elements.text: I’ve never looked into that before. Could be quite interesting though. Quite a bit of work betting programmatically with bookmakers though? Although there might be 3rd-party APIs you could go through I guess. Not sure about how widely exotics bets are exposed through those providers though.

text: There's a storied history of the likes of Bill Benter making literally billions out of the Hong Kong pools. With corona I'm looking at other options - I sort of assumed I just wouldn't be able to bet into the pools legally but then I found that article. And then I looked at a few of the mentioned bookmakers' websites and most of them said nothing about Hong Kong pools and the ones that did only had the standard pools.

text: You’ll struggle to win without a rebate

text: There are firms looking to get people to use apis to access asian betting markets. I can't remembered their names, but the head hunters approched me on LinkedIn when I said I was a professional gambler on LinkeIn. So if you want to learn more you can just update your linkedin profile and wait.

Does anyone happen to have a util to go from an estimated probability to the next up or down betfair tick? E.g. I want to back for the first price that implies 50.01% or more (this should go to 1.99) or I want to lay for any price that implies 50.01% or less (should go to 2.00). Following these <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Additional+Information#AdditionalInformation-BetfairPriceIncrements|increments>.

text:
I recently read the book Kelong Kings, it’s about football match fixing orchestrated by Singaporean/Chinese syndicates.

It’s quite possible in Asia (if you have the right contacts) to bet huge sums of money even on lowly matches. So those figures you mention are not surprising.

A far cry from the European bookies we’re used to dealing with :grinning:
